tweets.text: This recession is going to be a shit show. I hope it doesn't last too long. Best of luck to everyone out there could be rough for a while.

@pmje73 I would counter that with the suggestion that if you're not being rewarded for your work, it may not be as valuable as you think. 

The spirituality community being allergic to money and community does more to hurt its impact than help it IMO.
Niche question: what is the most effective business model for ethically and effectively combining spirituality and capitalism?
@pmje73 Idk call mid to high teens 3-5 yrs.

@pmje73 Thanks for always responding. I’m trying to better understand how to think about macro. Initially I thought of it from a global perspective but it seems to be more regionally specific. Tons of global growth tailwinds over the last decade and yet Europe has broadly lagged.
@pmje73 Macro in what sense?
@pmje73 Is this true for an individual company?
@pmje73 What’s your rule of thumb if a long goes up meaningfully in a short period of time for trimming or exiting to reallocate?  What % move up will you trim even if IRR still very attractive?
@AlphaBuke @pmje73 @Post_Market @OwenHydeNYC @ShortSightedCap This is a genuine question on your opinion.

@pmje73 @Post_Market @OwenHydeNYC @ShortSightedCap If I think the R/R is 3x? to the upside? Sheesh you have a high bar, yes I am buying if I think upside is 100 and downside is 30. Depends on your duration as well, but your point is taken. Just don't see a scenario where numbers get cut, SW gaps down, and I don't get excited.

@pmje73 @Post_Market @OwenHydeNYC @ShortSightedCap Agreed paul. But for software, it's harder to tell what "cut" needs to be given that I believe the durability here is going to be higher than investors are anticipating.

tweets.text:
@pmje73 @MadThunderdome @EnergyPeddler @CompoundingCap1 Somehow, discipline plays a meaningful role in LT success. Especially powerful late in the cycle.

Being able to refuse to participate when economics not in your favor is worthy first principle. Think it was much easier to exercise that discipline outside the hubs of NY and SF.

@pmje73 @MadThunderdome @EnergyPeddler @CompoundingCap1 I would reframe and say you should hold first principles fixed and maintain a growth mindset on the execution / tactics with “strong convictions held loosely”

@pmje73 @EnergyPeddler @CompoundingCap1 I think it's good to have principles that one follows. For instance, only invest in ethical management teams. Or never invest in fads. Tons of heuristics like this can keep you out of trouble.

@JerryCap @pmje73 @EnergyPeddler @CompoundingCap1 I think Marathon Asset Management's approach to investing where there has been a lack of supply is a principal that is consistent with a thought process of investing or speculation - call it what you want - where one can rotate between sectors/areas in a logical/disciplined way
@marketplunger1 @pmje73 @MadThunderdome @EnergyPeddler @CompoundingCap1 Pivoting implies that he would go back to cigar butts if he thought they would work. Had to scale with AUM.

@pmje73 True. But it also depends on when the grid was set. Given bb acceleration, I'm guessing it was set a while back before most of the bad news was obvious. They could have changed the 10b5-1 but there's a cool-off period so companies hate touching it, sometimes to their detriment.
@pmje73 It's a lot harder to manage buybacks than investors like to think. It's oftentimes a decision by committee with a lot of egos involved + investor pressure. Results will vary widely.

tweets.text:
SCIENCE:

If you don't make mistakes, you're doing it wrong.

If you don't correct those mistakes, you're doing it really wrong.

If you can't accept that you're mistaken, you're not doing it at all.

6) As a footnote, I prefer TTM to NTM P/E during times of uncertainty for all the obvious reasons.  i.e. TTM is a fact, NTM is a prediction.

Most other times that TTM multiples were contracting, there was risk to the NTM estimates because of a recession and/or rates were rising.

data.text: 5.) It’s always about price and time. Prices getting closer, but only if spreads don’t go much higher, secular growth not that that cyclical and roic still strong, just not peak. takes time to get these answers.  Prices can come quickly.  Price or time, which comes first?

4.) roic of the growth - cost of capital is rising so roic has to peak, I think. This isn’t just a ? for capital intensive companies. It’s for equity issuing intensive ones too. Does lower roic growth get a lower growth premium or is simply embedded in the lower eps?

3.) growth premium - secular growth always has an embedded cyclical tailwind and when it slows untangling the two takes quarters not weeks or months. What was secular and what is cyclical? What premium for growth was in stocks? What premium now?

2.) risk premium - credit spreads as a risk proxy have started to move.  Risk was mispriced narrowly off of artificially low rfr. If spreads keep moving up, equity risk premium keeps moving up.  What is catalyst to drive them higher?
1.) Risk free rate - for all the headlines this seems the most straight forward. The fed has been transparent & increasingly dovish. Rates have been quietly stable for a couple of weeks.

tweets.text:
@pmje73 @JerryCap I’m not fully understand this one as well. Can i put it this way, distinguishing those with clear sign of operating leverage? Is it different from what u said?
Ty for sharing ur thought 🙏
@pmje73 Why does roic have to peak because of an increase in cost of capital. Kd can effect ROE but not ROIC. Ke doesn't effect ROIC or ROE.

4.) roic of the growth - cost of capital is rising so roic has to peak, I think. This isn’t just a ? for capital intensive companies. It’s for equity issuing intensive ones too. Does lower roic growth get a lower growth premium or is simply embedded in the lower eps?

3.) growth premium - secular growth always has an embedded cyclical tailwind and when it slows untangling the two takes quarters not weeks or months. What was secular and what is cyclical? What premium for growth was in stocks? What premium now?

2.) risk premium - credit spreads as a risk proxy have started to move.  Risk was mispriced narrowly off of artificially low rfr. If spreads keep moving up, equity risk premium keeps moving up.  What is catalyst to drive them higher?
1.) Risk free rate - for all the headlines this seems the most straight forward. The fed has been transparent & increasingly dovish. Rates have been quietly stable for a couple of weeks.

tweets.text: @pmje73 @GavinSBaker @mjmauboussin The assumption was that these high revenue growth would eventually produce a normalized ROIC that would justify a future earnings multiple. We are seeing growth slow, competition increase pressuring long run margins and timelines for industries maturing being pushed out

@CrosscheckC @NTYCAPITAL @pmje73 How does rising usd affect margins? If it keeps rising is this baked into consensus / sentiment? I don’t know which stocks move on reported eps anymore anyway
@MadThunderdome @j_thomas_421 @pekwat Can you run the test?  Cancel without saying anything and see when they notice…?
@pmje73 Why would you not just look at constant currency growth and forecast or discount in usd if a company sells there

@pmje73 Any litmus test for differentiating between the two? Have rode semis and renewables only to get burned by e commerce and digitization, can’t seem to find a great framework for thinking about these
What is a stock/company that you know well that you can’t believe is down as much as it is?

@pmje73 Isn't the normal action to add net while cutting gross or keeping gross constant? 

I'm drawing an equivalence between covering shorts and adding longs as they each take cash and increase net. I find the psychology of covering to be different than buying long but idk why exactly.

Not sure if being levered changes things, but I was assuming gross long <100%.

Why is one harder/easier for you than the other?

@realdennishong @kennedy_joshua In fairness, fundamentals have been both v mixed and complex (comps, normalization, Rus, Eur, stim, fin conditions, etc). Agree the focus is too much on the P vs the E, but it’s also a hard forecasting environment. As a result, L3M and N3M get big focus and extrapolation

R1000 rolling correlation (constituents) has hit 59% which is the top decile historically.  It's the best zone for historical forward returns, implying that stocks are trading as an asset class, with little distinction between names. In English? Equals baby tossed w/ bathwater. https://t.co/ZN4LaW9DR7

@ProtagorasTO @pmje73 Shorting one stock may help you learn but you need to do it a lot if you really want to know how to do it. Frankly now is a tough time to learn as most shorts are working, which isn't normal.
Most important thing to learn is you need the people long the stock to want to sell.
@ProtagorasTO @MadThunderdome What’s your goal?
@pmje73 @MadThunderdome What's an easier baby step for a beginner?
@ProtagorasTO Don't short pancaked stocks.  Short something a little more contrarian where you have some idea that its going to deteriorate more than people expect.

Btw it takes huge guts to make moves like these. Allocators generally do not like fund managers to hold huge % of cash. Making market calls like this also hard and more often wrong than right. Bravo to stick to independent thinking and buck the pressure in doing this.

tweets.text: @MadThunderdome @MungerValue @hungry_cap @Post_Market @TheBenSchmark You could be right.  The other side is lower turnover means lower inventory.  If demand sustains that means we need more new homes.  And existing homes likely become more valuable which historically has led to more repair & remodel work
@MetacriticCap I guess I could make up a handful of ten year assumptions, pretend I know they will happen and then discount them back based on a few inputs I don’t control.  That might work too.
@pmje73 Funny way of investing.
@pmje73 If you hate DCFs, how do you derive intrinsic value?

5/ so if ke is up to 7.5-8 from 5-5.5 then we are pretty close to historical long run assumed avg ke. That means underlying 0 growth multiple is now 12-13x from peak of 18-20x? But has the underlying assumed growth or roic of that growth also changed within multiples? Justified?
4/ or was ke 5.5 or 18x? That seems like the range at mkt highs.  So that means growth premium was 3-5x multiple turns? Is that normal? @mjmauboussin @AswathDamodaran ? I have no idea.

3/ today, rf is 3. But erp is always a guess as is the growth premium. Erp does go up with credit spreads.  Rf is up 2 and erp is up .5 off the lows.  so ke is arguably up 2.5.  But what was underlying ke and what was baked in for growth?  Was ke 5% or 20x when mkt was 23x?

tweets.text: 2/stocks and the mkt are always pricing in some ke and assigning some multiple premium for future valuation creation.  So the formula for a stock is always rf + erp + some premium for eps growth based on an assumed LT roic.
What multiple would you pay for a “profitable” SaaS/consumer internet company that isn’t growing that fast anymore?

@pmje73 That’s prob right in certain pockets. But think investing in eg commods based on rational supply side is trickier than based on strength of demand. I guess I’m too cynical to believe people don’t eventually defect because of siren song of excess returns.

@pmje73 Fed telling you they need to bring down ngdp growth, either it works as planned, or they slam on brakes harder and cause recession. Least likely outcome is persistent ngdp growth at levels of last few years IMO. But maybe that’s in price since many trade at optically low mults https://t.co/w2dkzHqfrz

@pmje73 Q on cyclicals IMO is went from a decade of 4.5% ngdp growth, to 3 year CAGR of 7% while costs badly lagged rev growth, now ngdp growth decel’ing as costs catch up. Baseline level of profit prob ends up higher + ngdp 1pt > last cycle, which is +ive but next ~18 mos seems neg skew
@pmje73 I like glencore Paul!
@pmje73 US only, or open to ROW?
@pmje73 There are some good banks that have gotten interesting.
@pmje73 @jeffkeller1 @SteadyState15 @BATMongoose @Msp194 @MadThunderdome Meaning it’s impacted by secular shift and therefore not as instructive for a broader trend?

Seeing some small layoffs start (hood, blnd etc). FB reducing spend by a few $B is a few K less hires prob. VCs telling portCos to focus on burn.

High end could change quickly too

@pmje73 @MadThunderdome Do you think there are a subset of stocks that will be much higher 10 years from now? Aka AMZN in 2000. Or do you think everything will be lower permanently. I get you play the short term game but at a certain point it makes sense to load up on perceived winners when they’re down

Is it simply stupid valuations unjustifiable in any time frame even if biz is great or does the underlying asset/business need to be comically unsustainable?
@LimestoneFella Because everyone else is zoomed out.  Time to zoom in. Opposite of six months ago when everyone was zoomed in too close.

@scalethemis Depends how many ideas you need and how much you want to cover. I think a very narrow, concentrated fund can have same person wear the PM/analyst hat and probably do it better than most but will be volatile and narrow. I don’t think that model scales though
@SeminyakCapital @JohnStonkton4 Perhaps, certainly been the case that prior to 2021 some clowns have been feted as champs
@SeminyakCapital Of course.   Crappy teams can shine in speculative markets.  Poor teams with dominant PMs can shine in turbulent markets.  Crappy teams and dominant PMs can’t shine now imo.
I’ll restate differently something I said a few weeks ago. This is an ideal environment for high functioning analyst/PM teams and an amazing opportunity for analysts to shine … if PMs let them.

Constitution as the last great differentiator between and among investors is likely true but also often leads investors to isolate, suppress and deny emotions rather than develop a process to be aware, understand and manage those emotions and the decisions they lead to.

@tom_morganKCP @IgnoreNarrative @rogerw_chen @SweatyEquities If you’re already burned out, a simple challenge may seem like a grind.  Does the external stimuli determine the mindset/emotional response or does the mindset/emotional response dictate the handling of the external stimuli?
@tom_morganKCP @IgnoreNarrative @rogerw_chen @SweatyEquities The struggle is the job.  If you don’t like the struggle you don’t like the job. Everyone likes the spoils.

@dumbcapital @quakerheel @viggy_krishnan @Bonhoeffer_KDS @1MainCapital @PrefShares But like isn’t that the point? Anything between trading around q’s and 5 years isn’t PE in public markets so they are functionally equivalent relative to PE.
@viggy_krishnan @quakerheel @Bonhoeffer_KDS @1MainCapital @PrefShares I mean public in private means “please ignore my marks”. That’s all it means.
@stonetreelake @BazCap @1MainCapital I think mkt needs to move one way or the other.  It’s fence sitting right now imo and earnings will help people choose sides.  Buckle up.

@stonetreelake @BazCap @1MainCapital If you want max opportunity. Opportunity right now is pretty mediocre to poor.  Can burn that off peacefully or violently.  Just saying I’ve seen sweet opportunities after max pain and this ain’t that or even close.

@BazCap @1MainCapital Max opportunity comes at max pain.  With the exception of a handful of HFs caught way offsides nobody is max pain and anyone that thinks we experienced max pain in 1q doesn’t know max pain.

@1MainCapital @viggy_krishnan @PrefShares Your statement did express that. I wasn’t disagreeing. I was giving a simple rule of thumb. Do I think mgmt should do xyz or do I think mgmt is actually going to do xyz?  Do I think this should happen or is it actually starting to happen?

@1MainCapital @viggy_krishnan @PrefShares a thesis that states what you believe mgmt should do as if it’s actually what mgmt is going to do is very problematic and often has to be teased out because analysts can over intellectualize and think “of course that’s what’s going to happen” but you know mgmt and know it won’t.
@realKunalAShah @viggy_krishnan @1MainCapital @PrefShares Also true but at least in life you have some agency.  In passive public mkt investing your only agency buy and sell.
@1MainCapital @viggy_krishnan @PrefShares You don’t speak my language.  I never said will.

@1MainCapital @viggy_krishnan @PrefShares “Should” expresses a belief of “what ought to happen”. Great theses express what is true of the biz/mgmt, and what is likely to happen based on these truths not what ought to happen. You can wordsmith should to mean probably but great idea generators understand my distinction.
@viggy_krishnan @1MainCapital @PrefShares The word should gets you in a lot of trouble in public markets.
@IgnoreNarrative @compound248 Very Madoff like predictability

Dominant narrative from btfd investors has been “Powell can’t afford another taper tantrum”.  Could argue fed wanted to raise rates back then w/out breaking assets or the economy but now has to break inflation and if fed breaks assets and gdp too so be it. 🤷‍♂️🤔

urls.description: What links all of today’s fierce debates around policy, productivity, competition, and capitalism? tweets.text: Do you think about the GP commit / internal capital in a HF as working capital or capex?
@quakerheel @pmje73 @viggy_krishnan @Bonhoeffer_KDS @1MainCapital @PrefShares exactly
@pmje73 @BazCap @1MainCapital Fair enough. Seeing largely the same
@pmje73 @BazCap @1MainCapital Why must we experience “max pain?” Is this a foregone conclusion?

@pmje73 @viggy_krishnan @PrefShares Got it, I thought my statement implied what "ought to happen" rather than what "should" happen. Sorry for the confusion, and thanks for clarifying.

"You buy companies where mgmt and the board are allocating capital exactly how you would if you did have control."
@pmje73 @viggy_krishnan @1MainCapital @PrefShares And life…
@pmje73 @viggy_krishnan @PrefShares Maybe, but literally every single investment thesis whether long or short and whether in public or private markets has the word "should" in it.
@compound248 I’m old enough to remember getting that in stocks
@pmje73 Yeah feels like a buyers strike except periodic short covering. Only good things can happen here. 😬
@pmje73 Hedge funds have been degrossing pretty hard.  Net leverage across MS PB clients declined 3% last week. Best I can quantify.

tweets.text: What do you think when you hear someone say “I don’t need to pay HF fees to own XYZ.”

@pmje73 @marketplunger1 Fair. I remember reading (maybe from you itself) that one should avoid *forcing* a thesis when the prev one is invalidated to justify holding onto a stock - instead de anchor and truly test if a new thesis exists

data.text: @swisscottaging @marketplunger1 The problem though is with a great biz like snow you need to be ahead of those 2-3 expectation misses and then in front of the stabilization.  Some would rather just own through the decel.

@swisscottaging @marketplunger1 Nuanced q and raises a great distinction btwn great biz and great stock. Imo a thesis is actionable in a 15-24 month window so a stock that can’t work in that window is a busted thesis and need to underwrite a new thesis for the other side of the decel.  Opinions vary though.

data.text: @thechrisbuskirk Think it was public policy supporting private workers to work less for more money thereby lowering productivity, competitiveness and profitability.  The avg European company is structured similarly to NYC public schools.

Been asked often the difference between busted q and a busted thesis.  Hard to have a rule b/c fact dependent, but thinking a good heuristic is busted q usually caused by a missed single metric/# whereas a busted thesis is usually a broken algorithm that changes the narrative.

data.text: In 90s and 00s I would visit Euro co’s and all would emphasize “stakeholders” compared to the best US co’s that emphasized “total shareholder value.” Increasingly big US co’s sound and behave like those Euro co’s.  Post script - those euro stocks haven’t worked. At all.

@MadsenSouth First, define “risk”. Second, Great LPs ask great questions. If you want your GP to take more risk ask your GP the right questions. For example, a l/s fund with consistently great spread on consistently low gross the only question is “why is your gross always so low?”
@NTYCAPITAL Your framing is also very top line driven. Suspect best structural short concerns are margin driven for next 12-18 months.
@NTYCAPITAL Secular losers aren’t the best shorts imo.  Great to good and fallen angels better imo.
@1MainCapital @BazCap @InnocenceCapit1 @SteadyState15 No idea.  Not going to speculate.

@BazCap @InnocenceCapit1 @SteadyState15 I have no opinion or insight.  My general view is the bigger a fund gets the more important a dozen or so portfolio management rules become and should be strictly enforced.

@InnocenceCapit1 @SteadyState15 @BazCap Its a bit big but I think it can be done and done well at that scale. I just think when that large, gross has to swing wildly at least 2x a year or you are gonna increasingly take a punch in the gut. That’s fine too if everyone is on same page - LPs and employees.
@tom_morganKCP Enough to do what?

@InnocenceCapit1 @SteadyState15 @BazCap Best guess. 30 bn l/s fund at 150 gross/50 net (100 long and 50 short). LO down 36 and l/s down 34. That means shorts added 2 pts so longs down 36 and shorts down 4. -32 spread. No insight on positioning but I would bet that math is pretty close to accurate.

data.text: @MadThunderdome @MadsenSouth If you sit on a beach you will think about your pnl. If you downhill ski, mountain bike, scuba, rock climb, bungee jump, hunt … distracted equals hurt or dead.  If you play a racquet sport, golf, swim, etc … distracted means you suck.  Maybe that fire distracts you, maybe not.
@MadThunderdome @MadsenSouth Pick up a hobby that if you suck at it you die. Super easy to have a drink and get to a 3 afterwards.
@MadThunderdome @MadsenSouth Great friend highlighted to me that I was constantly simmering at an 7.5- 8.5 when I needed to toggle between a 3 and a 10. I didn’t understand at the time.  Do now.
@MadThunderdome And pray kids breaks are not during eps season

@MadThunderdome Travel on Fri so Sat and Sun are unwind days and you are already on vacay by Mon open. Check email and mkt btwn 930-10 and 330. Assign 1-2 people the ability to call to break your do not disturb. If nobody calls no reason to think.  If someone calls you know you need to answer.

@OrlandoBravoTB Disagree. Public mkt is great at snuffing out low quality by punishing stocks until the bd hires mgmt to deliver the quality you describe. Shorts hunt the crap.  Conversely mkt assigns high mults to best/highest quality mgmt. Short term mkt gets its wrong but never for too long.

@SkepticalTsar The same lack of dispersion that drove saas up is pulling it down.  If you were actually capturing spread between quality and crap on the way up you would have made less and lost less on the way down.  That’s fine but it’s not a 2/20 model.

@MetaBagholder @beyer71 @OrlandoBravoTB One variable is revenue when margins are established and expand slowly.  Multiple variables is revenue growth, duration of that growth and margins. Mkt will value the former more correctly than the latter.

@OrlandoBravoTB I would make a different observation.  The mkt is good at valuing v good but relatively narrow outcomes when one major variable is uncertain. The mkt is bad at valuing a wide range of outcomes with more than one uncertain variable.

data.text: @Post_Market @GooglePumpDump @cablecarcapital @KishenMehta I’m old enough to remember when hedge funds u/p by a little in raging markets and o/p by a lot in big down markets and that’s why the fees were justified.
@ComebackCap @hedgie007 You can also buy qual etf.  There is a moving definition of quality but the point is there are many options on the long only side to get long returns.

Odd when l/s funds claim to be u/p b/c quality longs are unfairly dragged down by the crap derating when l/s are designed to capture spread btwn quality & crap. Short is in the name of the strategy. If you only own the quality why are you charging 2/20?  There’s an ETF for that.
@MikeBucella They have similarities.  Both also very local and deal by deal dependent.
@ReductioAA @patrick_oshag Thanks been awhile since I read it!
@patrick_oshag Could go in a lot of directions - When things fall apart, Sundiata …. but I would read Leopolds Ghost or Dictatorland first and then zero in on a country like Uganda or Ethiopia.

@MylesDanielsen I would love to see $1 in a group of high flier funds peaked at what $ and finishes 23 where?  Compare that to steadier funds that u/p early and o/p late.  Is it very different? Did high fliers just get overpaid early and now work for free for a bit?

@fundiescapital You know me, I’m not great at skinny tails.  I would just be curious to see the high fliers with drawdowns vs the steady as we go without the steep peak or the sharp decline. Qqq are still up what 75? Good funds are probably up 50-60.  90th percent are up 100+.
@NTYCAPITAL L/s is not an asset class.  It’s a contract between two supposed consenting parties.
@bonefish4 Thought of that but most LPs that matter don’t pay taxes
Will be interesting to see where LPs net out of all fees from 1/1/20 to 1/1/23 in funds.  Would love to see that graphed.

@AReviewOrTwo1 @MadsenSouth @InnocenceCapit1 @BazCap @MadThunderdome @Biohazard3737 @iknownoothing @hungry_cap @SeminyakCapital @deliberate_cap @NYCJ3 @Chariot_Invest @MaldenDriveCap If you are a PM/founder and more than 50pct of your ideas originate from digging by analysts you should have a system/process everyone understands and buys in to. If you generate 75pct of your ideas it’s not worth your time to invest in now.

@AReviewOrTwo1 @MadsenSouth @InnocenceCapit1 @BazCap @MadThunderdome @Biohazard3737 @iknownoothing @hungry_cap @SeminyakCapital @deliberate_cap @NYCJ3 @Chariot_Invest @MaldenDriveCap Critical relationship skill development between analyst and PM is having rational frequent conversations distinguishing between signal and noise for existing positions.

@AReviewOrTwo1 @MadsenSouth @InnocenceCapit1 @BazCap @MadThunderdome @Biohazard3737 @iknownoothing @hungry_cap @SeminyakCapital @deliberate_cap @NYCJ3 @Chariot_Invest @MaldenDriveCap That’s always a fund by fund business model decision.  I believe in digging - analyzing - deciding. You dig, we analyze, i decide. If the analysis was based on bad info analyst was wrong. If I chased and paid 35x I’m wrong.

@MadThunderdome @InnocenceCapit1 @MadsenSouth @BazCap @Biohazard3737 @iknownoothing @hungry_cap @SeminyakCapital @deliberate_cap @NYCJ3 @Chariot_Invest @MaldenDriveCap I think it’s commercialism.  Ego is I’m great, ignore my faults and overpay me. Commercialism is please get the f out of my way and let me help US make money.

@MadsenSouth @InnocenceCapit1 @BazCap @MadThunderdome @Biohazard3737 @iknownoothing @hungry_cap @SeminyakCapital @deliberate_cap @NYCJ3 @Chariot_Invest @MaldenDriveCap And the last and most important point is that if you invert my order of observations and have a culture where the founder says “I” when things go well and “we” or “you” when they don’t you have the trickle down culture you cultivated and of course the analysts will adopt it.

@MadsenSouth @InnocenceCapit1 @BazCap @MadThunderdome @Biohazard3737 @iknownoothing @hungry_cap @SeminyakCapital @deliberate_cap @NYCJ3 @Chariot_Invest @MaldenDriveCap If you are an analyst and lose money 3 out of 5 years you get fired.  PM at a pod shop, fired.  Fund founders get fired if the lose money 3 out of the first 5 years.

data.text: @StateScoolMath @ebitdaddy90 @patrick_oshag @atelicinvest Not sure I understand your algorithm.  I think a thesis is - revenue, margin and/or capital allocation view that drives higher or lower eps/FCF vs expectations.   There are probably 25 different types of rev thesis, 10 GM theses, 6-8 opex and a handful of allocation ones.

@ebitdaddy90 @patrick_oshag @atelicinvest My idea is thesis driven vs quality driven.  For example, a classic revenue thesis is - low price, small player share taker under large player price umbrella.
@ebitdaddy90 @patrick_oshag @atelicinvest Yes a good 1.0 version of what I was thinking

@patrick_oshag @atelicinvest @ebitdaddy90 I also think you can create a manual of ideas podcast series. There are maybe 40-50 unique idea frameworks. I think you can encounter unique company fact patterns and match to a framework.  It’s the only book I’ve ever thought about writing but I’m really lazy.

data.text: @AReviewOrTwo1 I think this is where having a contrarian instinct helps.  Everyone looking for the next great saas name when they are all trading at extreme multiples rather than asking about shorts? Everyone has low gross and net, only talking about the fed and risk ….

This may seem like a small distinction but I believe most underperformance by institutional mgrs is caused by failing to toggle wisely from PM to analyst and back and forth.  Analysts fall in love with stocks PMs dont. PMs fall in love with trend following, analysts dont.
@Alt_Trader1 Think everyone is trying to predict regime and market direction.  The discourse has shifted from stocks to market.  I think that’s a good time to find new stock ideas.
2h21 instinct was to remove analyst hat and focus on PM hat and risk management. Increasingly thinking it’s time to switch back to analyst hat as everyone else plays closet market strategist.
@jaminball I would amend could to “will” and the analysis is “by how much”
@JerryCap @DKThomp Agree thanks for sticking  with it despite my original response ….
@JerryCap @DKThomp I’m going to delete the initial response because I see how it can misinterpreted

@JerryCap @DKThomp Ha. Wish we had a leader say - look they don’t do all they were promised to do but they keep vulnerable people from dying for sure and may offer extra protection for everyone so if you are vulnerable get it and if you are nervous get it. And here’s who we consider vulnerable …
@JerryCap @DKThomp We also let powerful unions driven by fear and power force people to get them because we allow it to be intentionally ambiguous about whether they slow spread meaningfully.

@JerryCap @DKThomp I see it as people that “need” them.  If you don’t want one and need one you should be persuaded why it’s in your interest. My issue is we make people who don’t need them get them because there are too many people who need them that don’t want them and refuse to get them.

data.text: @JerryCap @DKThomp I’ll give you a simple example.  In CT if you get Covid and are age 0-30 you have had a 0.001% chance of dying.  If you are over 80 and got Covid you had a 25% chance of dying.  Why isn’t that always the starting point of every single analysis and policy?
@JerryCap @DKThomp That’s a fair point
@JerryCap @DKThomp Or maybe the best outcome is to define the vulnerable and be honest about their risks and focus on them rather then pretend everyone is equally vulnerable
@JerryCap @DKThomp Your response has a lot of assumptions.  Why don’t you define what “works” means today? And what “works” mean a year ago?

@JerryCap @DKThomp IMO this entire process has been reductive. Risk is simply threat times vulnerability. To reduce vulnerability you can attempt to avoid or resist the threat. How aggressively one needs to avoid or resist the threat is dependent on their inherent vulnerability to the threat.

data.text: @ABrother_Seamus @MadThunderdome Stocks are driven by eps and multiples sustainably.  Multiples are driven by risk free rate and equity risk premium. Eps is driven by revenue, margins, and capital allocation.  That’s the baseline. From there it’s always about rate of change relative to price.
@MadThunderdome The only real sustainable bull cases ever are low multiples, liquidity driven multiple expansion, low margins, accelerating revenue growth.  I don’t see many of these.
@modestproposal1 @jaminball Equity risk premium is also materially impacted by QE driven liquidity.  Can’t just look at rates v multiples.  Not the whole picture.
@MadThunderdome Yeah it’s interesting.  We could have a shallow recession with autos and housing growing through it and without a meaningful credit cycle.
@HotspurInvestor @nomad_capital Read it again and see where i connect that to the chart.
@JerryCap @PythiaR But also need to add switching costs up and down the chain
@JerryCap @PythiaR Well said.
@JerryCap Depends on 3 things imo - 1.) barriers to crossover, 2.) growth of primary market, and 3.) happiness with share of primary market
@nomad_capital Where did I say I was concluding anything from this chart.

data.text: The most exciting time to deploy capital is when stocks are within 10% of where you’d been hoping to buy bigly and can’t decide whether to wade in slowly or say f it and make a full bet.  Given inflation uncertainty im leaning towards the former but don’t feel great about it tbh.
@StateScoolMath Too soon

@valuekid @InnocenceCapit1 Think it’s more likely E is lower due to margins than revenue in the businesses I like but there is def going to be negative revisions.  I’m factoring that in to the names I am thinking of.

@InnocenceCapit1 I would bet people buy these levels. Either buy em now and maybe take a 10-15pct drawdown or don’t buy em now and they buy them on the way back up but these are levels that get bought in a crazy number of stocks.

4q21 valuations made no sense over almost any reasonable investment time horizon. 
Todays valuations aren’t perfect but they are getting interesting and todays valuations in 3-4 months would start approaching sexy times.
@LSValue @MadThunderdome Fed backing off would be bearish imo.
This is an environment where your top 5 longs will drive performance more than your total long book and conversely your short book in totality will matter more than your few favorite shorts.

data.text: @patrick_oshag Ja Morant

A flaw of young companies is attacking a shiny new object in an adjacent vertical, geography or other horizontal opportunity/product before mastering everything in its immediate path. The discipline to not act in this manner necessarily increases when capital is scarcer.

I wish every large cash flowing company would generate a report like this for its shareholders.  Rich Templeton of TXN underrated as a leader and capital allocator.

data.text: @scalethemis @realdennishong @rsandler21969 @JerryCap i think investors can be great on 30 businesses at a time.  if you try to do more you dilute what you know.  if you want to do a new one you have to drop 1.  you can never outsource the initial learning.  you can leverage others for maintenance but not understanding.

@modestproposal1 @GavinSBaker @realdennishong @rsandler21969 @JerryCap i now try to distinguish between selling for cash v selling for a better idea. selling a blow off top, -ve fwd 2-3 yr IRR for cash is easy. selling the marginal "ehh now its an 8 IRR" for cash i need to be patient and look for a thesis to get me to 15-20 or replace it w/ a 20-30
@JerryCap @Sankaty_Head @realdennishong @rsandler21969 On avg no.

@realdennishong @rsandler21969 @JerryCap As an example I have now owned tmus for years and I am now on thesis 3.  I have flexed that position up a lot when the thesis was highly actionable and down when it was transitioning thesis. Balanced paying a little tax and working the capital.

@realdennishong @rsandler21969 @JerryCap And if I am guilty of one thing repeatedly it’s selling after thesis 1, paying taxes and buying for thesis 2. I’ve def worked harder to search for the continuous handoff rather than sell and look for a reason to return.

@realdennishong @rsandler21969 @JerryCap For me it’s always about two questions - current thesis reflected in consensus? No? Great; yes? Do I have another thesis that’s not crazy long dated that I think will keep it growing at the same or faster rate that’s not reflected in consensus.

@rsandler21969 @JerryCap Imho LT compounding in a single biz in public markets is derived by either being lazy and lucky; or underwriting the position from thesis to thesis similar to handing a baton from runner to runner over yrs. AMZN has been driven by a handful of great theses over 20 yrs.
@CLErainmaker Umm 2020-2021
@RobertSimmons 💯
@RobertSimmons Valuation supports the thesis, it’s not the entire thesis

Strongly believe thesis driven and valuation supported ideas rather than “biz quality” ideas are what will continue to hold up best and outperform for awhile. Thesis prompt - 2-3 reasons why the stock will work 2h22-24 before mentioning “it’s a great biz” or “it’s really cheap”
@MadThunderdome Broke going up.
@modestproposal1 Yup
@marketplunger1 Where is next level of support?

data.text: @MMMembrado @atelicinvest @clown_cap @chiwizardry Months
@atelicinvest @clown_cap @chiwizardry I suspect we will have an extended bottoming process more than a reversal
@Post_Market Maybe that gets you 30x sustainably rather than 25-30x?

Let's use COST to illustrate recent multiple expansion on great biz.  Traded at 25-30x 1 yr fwd PE for a decade. In the trough of the 18 sell off, it bottomed at 25x.  Expanded to a peak of 45x on 11/26.  Now 38x. Why is that remotely attractive unless #s are 35% too low?
this is still normal.
This guy is actually worse than deblasio.  Inconceivable. https://t.co/3Pzeye9zcd
@DebatingMarkets you have to factor in size and continued growth at end of measurement period.

for example, paying 20x 1 yr fwd revs for an eventual  30% margin biz in year 7 that you expect will trade at 30x fcf on year 8 fcf must cagr revs 38% over those 7 years to earn a 20% IRR.  that should be the default saas hurdle.

imho target rev mults are useless.  take the 1yr fwd rev mult you are paying, choose a duration (i like 5-7 yrs), target fcf margins at yr 5-7, choose fcf multiple at period end, & calculate implied rev cagr during that period.  if co can beat that cagr handily buy the stock.

@jaminball Rev mults require four assumptions - end point duration, rev growth to the end point, margins and multiple at that same end point. The trouble with rev multiples is everyone only talks about the rev growth in a period not the duration of the period or margins/end multiple.

@jaminball Can’t answer that question without discussing margin structure and magic number.  Failing to account for those is what gets you inflated unsustainable multiples to begin with so why try to go back to the same paradigm.
@atelicinvest Shooting the generals is normally a fairly late stage phenomenon
These market internals are starting to reflect fear.  So everyone with those fancy market psychology charts, this is what fear looks like.
@BenFranksAltEgo @MadThunderdome I think so

@MadThunderdome Short term yes 
Long term changes strategy and begins a secular shift
@BazCap @MadThunderdome Certainly a softening on tone in the way it’s being reported.
@eamonnmahn @MadThunderdome @BazCap Agree on the last point.  The first point was always just a threat in my mind.

data.text: @Post_Market @Negative_GW I mean there are stock and sector specific exceptions in both directions. I’m talking clean, safe stories.  Msft now trades at 20x 23.  Could it go down another 10-12 and trade at 17-18x?  That’s about as clean as you get.  Other stuff will over shoot more but won’t feel clean.

@IFTF6 @BillBrewsterTBB @nikzealand Every stock will stop going down when anchored to a valuation or time passes to get to that valuation. Doesnt have to be PE. 8-20x sales can be easily equated to PE multiples if there are gross margins and roi.  Hard to say that with 30-50x sales or 1/1000 of potential TAM.
@BillBrewsterTBB @nikzealand Broad brush is a start. Happy to discuss nuance but character limits and in bear markets start with the thesis and then work to find the exceptions.

@nikzealand Usually works out that 20-23x safe names outperform on the way down and underperform on the way up. The key will be competing safe higher multiple outperformers out with 15-18x scary names. That’s how 2h22 and 2023 alpha will be made.

data.text: @ZinvestZ you are quoting 22 multiples not 1 year forward target multiples.  I nor you have any clue what 23 spx eps will be but there are stocks you can narrow the goalposts.

In order to be excited for the upside to a 20-22x target multiple you need to overshoot and trade at 17x. Why? Because if it’s a good biz and can grow 20 then in a year the 17x will be sub 15x if it’s flat and that’s not going to happen to good businesses.

data.text: Over 12-18 months dating back to November, multiples will reset to 20-22x, saas and other rev mult stocks will have the cull herded and shitcos will go away.  This is all very normal. It’s just happening with a visible war, Covid, inflation, and toxic political theater.

10 years ago stocks were cheap, target mult for real biz went from 17x to 20x to 25x to 30x gradually with eps growing. saas came along and got same target eps multiples on theoretical long term eps but no actual ebit.  Shitcos got mkt cap based on TAM or nothing.

@NTYCAPITAL 3 year doubles.  When you have a dozen stocks you think are doubles on 25 eps on rational multiples, bother aggressive nor draconian.  That’s when you take up your gross immfho.

He said he’s telling kids: “When you have big brothers and sisters, sometimes they do it first to make sure it’s safe for you.” #MorningsOn1 https://t.co/qb7WZBIJZ4

@pmje73 30x fwd FCF still pretty substantial premium to several of worlds best large cap tech companies as of today...have always wondered why EV/revs crowd underwrites such high exit FCF multiples on bizs that are almost by def more risky than top of QQQ

imho target rev mults are useless.  take the 1yr fwd rev mult you are paying, choose a duration (i like 5-7 yrs), target fcf margins at yr 5-7, choose fcf multiple at period end, & calculate implied rev cagr during that period.  if co can beat that cagr handily buy the stock.

@pmje73 Of course. Trouble with revenue multiples in general for software companies - they're really a LT FCF multiple. Many companies won't hit those targets, making their revenue multiple over inflated / obsolete.

Impossible for a plug and play framework, but fun to think about :)

@realdennishong @Post_Market @nachkari There is a better model here to do single family rent to buy.  Rental rates give them an immediate pricing mechanism for renter and themselves. All of the funds centered around this model gave a limited life.  Open could be the evergreen option.

@Post_Market @nachkari That’s the key. As a seller, I want the highest price with a fast close preferably cash with minimal brokerage fees. As a buyer, I want wide selection at the cheapest price and move into the house as fast as possible. IMO, OPEN’s customer promise is neither of these things today.

@pmje73 @JerryCap I’ve never understood why anyone uses EV for public companies. You have no control over the balance sheet and your opinion of solvency is a binary go/no-go decision. EV makes sense in private markets where the buyer decides how to lever the business.

data.text: None of the policies now beginning to fade away had anything to do with the peak in cases and dramatic decline in Covid.  The virus did that all by itself when it mutated to omicron.
@GrowthStockGuy either works for different reasons.  ideally if you get gross margin expansion it flows to ebit.  sometimes you just get a more efficient spend of GP $s.  thats good too.
@XLFstocks Both
@XLFstocks Discounted how? What’s your math?

Three things solve most reasonable stock problems - accelerating revenue growth, margin expansion and accretive buybacks. If you don’t see line of sight on 1, or ideally 2 of these, then the problem in your portfolio might not have a great solution for a while
@Post_Market @DKThomp Would be great to see daily commuters to Manhattan by year and method of commute.  Would bet the metro north/lirr specific stats are dire.

data.text: @DKThomp Is that chart evidence of an office phenomenon for sure you think or some combo of office and the political/civil environment in nyc?
@AnotherCharlieH That’s the job in a nutshell
@AnotherCharlieH Meaning net long but the beta of my shorts higher than the beta of my longs

@HellRazor2379 The context was gross exposure and uncertain situation.  The more controversial an individual idea, the greater the potential outcomes, the greater the conviction, the bigger the bet ….

@HellRazor2379 Context def matters. However all else being equal if you are cutting your net by adding to your gross on a short term macro fear by 40 pts you are likely losing money on the 40 and covering.
@AnotherCharlieH Never done it. Been beta net short but not absolute.
@LimestoneFella Sure but weighing probabilities

Don’t misinterpret prior comment.  Simply means don’t add gross to hedge your worries. It’s too short a period of time and too much uncertainty. If you are worried about something get rid of it and double down in what doesn’t worry you.  Or do nothing and take the mark.
@NapkinCapital @JerryCap Bad analogy.  You can make money, but if you do, will do so narrowly.
I have never in my experience seen a risky, uncertain situation be managed effectively by adding gross exposure. Not once.

data.text: On the generalist v specialist debate I see sometimes on twitter I think the answer is both. Be a serial specialist. Major in a sector, minor in another, once you get a PhD in your major, make your minor your major and continue until you’ve gotten all the PhDs you want/need.

data.text: @Post_Market Still figuring out some of the better content on here but @jasonfurman is great on inflation and rates. On sellside I think degraaf at @RenMacLLC is best on spreads and zervos at Jefferies does the best job of explaining how equities are driven by the fed and bond mkt

I love WB and I’m down to quote him whenever but think he was wrong that the first rule of investing is don’t lose money.  Think the first rule of investing is “know thy self”, and sometimes you gotta lose a lil money to figure out exactly who you are.

@afterwt I think your alpha curve matters here. Do you lose money on every position for 1-3 months and then it rips or do you make money day 1? Do you exit early or late? I think these decisions determine the exact cadence. I am better off doing an extra 2 days of digging and then acting

@afterwt I was thinking fully baked and own then maintain until needing to act again vs half baked then whip it around based on whim. People too often do their best work at the start and then get lazy or anchored.
@LeakyBucket_ @afterwt Depends on your personal alpha curve but certainly can work

Reposting this cause I like the simplicity. 

Idea cadence shouldn’t be:
dig, think, act, act, act, act, act, act ….

Should be more like:
dig, think, act, dig, dig, think, dig, think, think, think, dig, think, act.

@InnocenceCapit1 @GavinSBaker Think the cadence is something like this 
dig, think, act, act, act, act, act, act 
when it should be 
dig, think, act, dig, dig, dig, think, think, think, act.

Adobe subscription transition viewed cautiously was major +ve

JCP hiring RJ and changing the entire retail strategy going everyday low prices was an epic blunder.
@atelicinvest I think bezos built it this way intentionally but the rest are kind of oblivious

Business “transitions” have been the greatest source of long and short ideas in my career. I think the reason is b/c transitions are difficult to analyze and lend themselves to reasoning by analogy rather than reasoning by first principles.

@atelicinvest I think your answer is right.  I highlight 50margin b/c if you generate $1 of revs that throws off 50c ebit, there are many ways to reinvest in 15c ebit $s but there better be 3-4x $ rev opp’ty.  If you generate 5c ebit and invest in 30-50c ebit per $ you offset size problem.
@atelicinvest Used ebit as a proxy for ebitda less capex but fair point
@atelicinvest What does it have to do with?
@tyler_zon The latter

data.text: Maybe we should just outlaw all risk taking in America of any kind. People are too stupid to understand risk so save them from themselves. It’s the only answer for the human stagnation we’ve seen over the last century. https://t.co/hvcJ6G1A80
“To choose an option, rationally, is to choose the associated explanation. Therefore, rational decision-making consists not of weighing evidence but of explaining it.” - David Deutsch

@GavinSBaker @wolfejosh I think you guys are both hitting on something. Fundamentals and valuations unlikely to cause 80% drop in major names, shitcos yes but major names no.  An ongoing rate/qe regime change, mkt liquidity and mkt structure can cause a systemic shock though. Then it gets reflexive.

A great stock picker can learn to be a great LO PM imo. A great short seller may never learn to manage a short book. It is the hardest skill to develop and I’m not sure can be taught. Those that manage real short books know what I mean. Much respect to those that do. 👊

@JohnStonkton4 Suspect there is no greater signal than running a concentrated portfolio and thriving.  If you aren’t great and run concentrated you probably blow up.  I always assume people who care what I think do this for a living and want to be great. There is a bias in all I say.
@DicksonPau I’m his words - Soros has taught me that when you have tremendous conviction on a trade, you have to go for the jugular. It takes courage to be a pig.

Bulls make $, bears make $, and pigs get slaughtered. I strongly believe the only way to make long-term returns that are superior is by being a pig. I think diversification and all the stuff they’re teaching at b school is probably the most misguided concept everywhere - Druck

data.text: 9/ I see too many covid policies based on power not authority.  If the data and evidence to support that power was still clear today. Not a year ago. Today.  The explanation and data could convert that power to authority.  Make people understand. Don’t just tell them to comply.

8/ In a true decentralized consensus building process, power doesn’t work. In markets, consensus saway from side to side power doesn’t work.  In science you must persuade. Ideas should be anti fragile.  Power shouldn’t exist. In politics power can dominate.
7/ with power. Power is exercising dominion over someone because you can’t explain properly what they need to do for themselves.  Do this or else!!!!

6/ with authority. Authority is the ability to persuade others to do as you suggest because your explanation is so clear they believe you are an authority and trust your opinion. Our country is different than others this way.
5/ when an individual is empowered to solve a problem for society the individual can approach the decision in one of two ways.
4/ when a market is the ultimate arbiter in solving the problem, math usually wins just a question of how long it takes the market to weigh the math vs the narrative.

How can the market decline with those kind of inflows and probably well over 15Bn of buybacks this week alone. Serious question. https://t.co/lDm1d3OmO1
@pmje73 @Post_Market @jasonfurman @RenMacLLC I like Kolanovic for macro at JPM, aka Gandolf, but Cornerstone guys are also very good.

@pmje73 I was hoping for some sagacity. It depends if you are sector spread or absolute return focused, but I perceive you can either size each short larger (dangerous), have a sleepier structural decliner “bond like” thesis (hurts alpha), or chunkier longs to free up time.

@pmje73 Let me see: good first take, PM mulls over, starter position, desktop work for analyst, do the calls, nagging risk / lynchpin identified, final calls on previous point, on fence about valuation / conviction, earnings and or price action, investment memo/trade note, core position?

@afterwt @pmje73 This works for a longer dated thesis. If you have a good first take, but suspect it will become consensus over the next few weeks, I find you need to move even faster. P Lynch: “Things are almost never clear on Wall Street, or when they are it is too late to profit from them”
@pmje73 @GavinSBaker yeah, i agree with that. i'm always updating work, but generally fight the urge to do very much.

@ProtagorasTO @pmje73 Yea where is the 50% number from? Don't think I've seen much data but 2/3 quit after 6 months was an early Uber churn number that wasn't so good.

I think churn is still bad but good news is lots of products like loyalty programs that can improve the numbers.
@InnocenceCapit1 Different for different people.  There is no "better" way to invest.  Just have to find what is "better" for your own emotional makeup.
@pmje73 @Post_Market @Deezee1031 buying *low* and selling *high* is the trick, you see
@pmje73 US supply constrained so maybe more like 20%, 30%, 50%.

tweets.text: Business “transitions” have been the greatest source of long and short ideas in my career. I think the reason is b/c transitions are difficult to analyze and lend themselves to reasoning by analogy rather than reasoning by first principles.

I do get the sense that most of these guys don't really even think about margins... just go for 10x bigger assume margins / economics gets taken care of.

tweets.text:
@pmje73 i.e. facebook would have the same problem even if it had lower margins. It's not too different from the problem that Buffett faces. 

Facebook core has been super profitable for very long time - there wasn't an issue of how to reallocate these dollars when they were a $30B co.

@pmje73 return on capital. Plenty of leasing businesses with 50% margins that earn 12% return on capital, whose fortunes would improve if they can allocate that dollar to a 20% margin business with much lower capital intensity.

(I said I was being nitpicky...)
@pmje73 Not to be nitpicky but don't think it has much to do with ebit margins tbh.
@pmje73 Are you saying its hard to maintain those margins and still grow? Or that you can’t run a 70% EBIT margin biz and find a lot of things offer good comparable returns?

urls.title: Omicron and Original Antigenic Sin
urls.description: A small study of breakthrough infections provides further evidence that Omicron likely benefits from immune imprinting, or Original Antigenic Sin, in the vaccinated. The authors, mostly from UC San Francisco and UC Berkeley, conducted neutralisation assays on 144 plasma samples from 81 individuals, 63 of them double-vaccinated, and 18 of them boosted. None of the subjects had been infected prior to vaccination, but 53 suffered breakthrough infections. Thirty-nine of these breakthroughs were probably Delta, and 14 were Omicron.

tweets.text: 9/ I see too many covid policies based on power not authority.  If the data and evidence to support that power was still clear today. Not a year ago. Today.  The explanation and data could convert that power to authority.  Make people understand. Don’t just tell them to comply.

8/ In a true decentralized consensus building process, power doesn’t work. In markets, consensus saway from side to side power doesn’t work.  In science you must persuade. Ideas should be anti fragile.  Power shouldn’t exist. In politics power can dominate.
7/ with power. Power is exercising dominion over someone because you can’t explain properly what they need to do for themselves.  Do this or else!!!!

6/ with authority. Authority is the ability to persuade others to do as you suggest because your explanation is so clear they believe you are an authority and trust your opinion. Our country is different than others this way.
5/ when an individual is empowered to solve a problem for society the individual can approach the decision in one of two ways.
4/ when a market is the ultimate arbiter in solving the problem, math usually wins just a question of how long it takes the market to weigh the math vs the narrative.
3/ all problems i like to attack involve narrative and math. The key. To solving the problem is finding the inconsistencies between the two.

data.text: 3/ all problems i like to attack involve narrative and math. The key. To solving the problem is finding the inconsistencies between the two.

2/analyzing a problem for me is similar regardless of the problem. Dig for info, analyze what you find, assess what is driving the problem to be solved, have an opinion with conviction then decide.  If I choose to share that opinion it’s my job to persuade.
@preluder Cite the data. Don’t use adjectives. The data is not clear. It should be a choice.

@SuperMugatu @patrick_oshag How do they define success

@amankapadia @MadThunderdome @Deezee1031 @special_cheeese just a caution not to look at tenants per tower in Europe and think they can catch USA.  That’s all.  Have heard that pitch and don’t think it’s possible.  growth will come from new builds and escalators but not v much from lease up of existing towers. Solid algo.
@PhilTListener @ToplelWhonk Fair point. I own four asset classes. Concentrated within all of them.

@MadThunderdome @amankapadia @Deezee1031 @special_cheeese Pop density in Europe different than usa. us 3rd party tower model going on 30 years of build to suit anchor tenant colo because it made $ sense to share in wide search rings.  Eu was mostly carrier built for v long time so the unit economics of legacy towers just v different.
@brentmuio @ebitdaddy90 @qcapital2020 Yes for sure but don’t see data suggesting has been a driver of ytd vol.

@amankapadia @viggy_krishnan @MadThunderdome @Deezee1031 @special_cheeese That’s my point.  New build great but legacy portfolio different than us so just need to think about the rev algorithm differently if experience is first learning us towercos.

@MadThunderdome @Deezee1031 @special_cheeese Towers are unsecured creditors of telcos.  They will get paid always. Cellnex issue is trying to facilitate passive network sharing rather than traditional us telco like colo because unlike us towers, most European towers weren’t built to support as many tenants as us towers.

@ebitdaddy90 @qcapital2020 I think I said this on iltb but massive, centralized AUM managers, active and passive, combined with an increasingly electronic and decentralized trading structure will certainly lead to periodic spikes of massive vol.  then add floating leverage when prime and ofr were 0. Whoa.

@ebitdaddy90 @qcapital2020 @patrick_oshag By changing mkt structure I mean electronic, quant driven mkt structure where larger block pools of liquidity are hard to find and when all is calm contribute to rising tide but when volatile result in a stampede

@ebitdaddy90 @qcapital2020 Etf volume as a pct of mkt volume up as much as 50pct q/q on some days. Perhaps @patrick_oshag or others have better data.  Last year it was retail. This year seems like passive. Combined with changing mkt structure and liquidity is a problem even in giant names.
Final comment before logging off for the weekend. During volatility get more concentrated not less. Diversification is for dentists.

1-2x per year the market gives you a chance to upgrade your portfolio to what you want to own for the next few years not what you wish you had owned for the last few months

urls.title: #73: A Chess Prodigy on Mastering Martial Arts, Chess, and Life
urls.description: Listen to this episode from The Tim Ferriss Show on Spotify. Josh Waitzkin was the basis for the book and movie Searching for Bobby Fischer. This episode is DEEP, in the best way possible. Considered a chess prodigy, he has perfected learning strategies that can be applied to anything, including his other loves of Brazilian jiu-jitsu (he’s a black belt under phenom Marcelo Garcia) and Tai Chi Push Hands (he’s a world champion). These days, he spends his time coaching the world’s top performers, whether Mark Messier, Cal Ripken Jr., or hedgefund managers. I initially met Josh through his incredible book, The Art of Learning. Our first long conversation on the podcast (#2) can be found on iTunes or here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LYaMtGuCgm8 ***If you enjoy the podcast, would you please consider leaving a short review on Apple Podcasts/iTunes? It takes less than 60 seconds, and it really makes a difference in helping to convince hard-to-get guests. I also love reading the reviews!F

data.text: 2/Stock reasons - 1/thesis is broken. ex pton. Sell, find new thesis & re-buy, or never look back. 2/thesis replaced by more bullish thesis you don’t believe. ex spot. Own it for xyz, works & thesis morphs to xyz cubed. Peace out. 3/so expensive, 0 chance buy 20-30% lower. Trim.

A 🧵to add to this conversation
My 3 categories of reasons to sell a stock: 
1.) stock reasons,
2.) portfolio reasons, or 
3.) Risk mgmt reasons. 
Stock/portfolio reasons lead to trimming or selling & deploying to another idea. Risk mgmt leads to de-levering or raising cash. https://t.co/oot73oTWaR

@realdennishong @MadThunderdome @MadsenSouth I’m not dogmatic about how we get there. Cost of supply can kill demand. Magnitude of demand can continue to overwhelm supply. Macro factors can crush either.  I’m not predicting the future I’m just trying to carefully watch the present.

@MadThunderdome @MadsenSouth I look at the problem like this, durable goods demand is running above trend and services demand is running below trend. What happens to inflation if they both get back on trend naturally? If unable to get there naturally what would it take to get us there in either or both?
@chrishlad Sometimes having more confidence than skill is better than having more skill than confidence

@BeaglierCap I have never seen great ones.  For newbies hagstrom is good but v basic

@StateScoolMath Gross is always a function of 
upside/downside of ideas
stability of risk free rates
equity risk premium with high yield and credit spreads as a proxy

A way to think about portfolio construction is with a mind toward maximizing the # of 500 bps winners while limiting the potential for 50+ bps losers. So much attention gets lost on stock % moves rather than bps impact to performance while that ratio is what drives performance.

tweets.text: 2/Stock reasons - 1/thesis is broken. ex pton. Sell, find new thesis & re-buy, or never look back. 2/thesis replaced by more bullish thesis you don’t believe. ex spot. Own it for xyz, works & thesis morphs to xyz cubed. Peace out. 3/so expensive, 0 chance buy 20-30% lower. Trim.

A 🧵to add to this conversation
My 3 categories of reasons to sell a stock: 
1.) stock reasons,
2.) portfolio reasons, or 
3.) Risk mgmt reasons. 
Stock/portfolio reasons lead to trimming or selling & deploying to another idea. Risk mgmt leads to de-levering or raising cash. https://t.co/oot73oTWaR
Great thoughts from Michael here https://t.co/EEv23L6pmg
@MadThunderdome @Keubiko Should get a good read on this from $AVLR and $ADYEN. 2022 may be omni over e commerce.

@k95984624 @pmje73 Usually when stock grow into their multiple they stop going up or drastically underperform other ideas. Your job as a PM is to view stocks that you don’t own as competing for your capital. If there are better ideas they should displace an old idea. Active Mgmt. Key word active.
@pmje73 it would be a mistake to attribute our entire fatality gap to anti-vaxx sentiment, but it's also a mistake to say the difference is "just" obesity.

@HellRazor2379 Great q. Happen across them all. Some omissions, some commissions.
Consensus longs you either miss cause consensus or get lazy. 
Great longs miss cause early and get tired of waiting for the narrative to turn. 
Consensus shorts see AMC
Great shorts always always too early.

@WAndreasyan Usually means the narrative supports looking at one thing but the math of something more important will eventually win out.  For example, user growth may dominate narrative but the underlying unit economics of the users are actually deteriorating.

Been thinking about the following and think it’s accurate:

Great Math + Great Narrative = Consensus Long

Great Hidden Math + Bad Current Narrative = Great Long Thesis 

Bad Math + Bad Narrative = Consensus Short 

Bad Hidden Math + Great Current Narrative = Great Short Idea

@1MainCapital True and Ive said exact same thing, but if you write a $300 million check shouldnt you have some bargaining power?

@Sg423Sg i believe in active portfolio mgmt on longs and shorts.  i am not in the never sell crowd. Shorts are trickier because they get bigger not smaller so it requires a different set of skills.  a great many PMs would see the PTON blowup and cover if short; or kick themselves if not.

@1MainCapital The big guys have tilted levered long w/ weak or no shorts.  LPs allow the wealth transfer. Emerging l/s funds target and capture spread & sing for their supper. I work with emerging mgrs and wonder why no shift in LP allocations or deflation. I’m pro disruption in all things.
@1MainCapital I’m a l/s purist.
@ShortBusCap Emphasis on old. Ain’t no major cubs the best short sellers anymore. Not even close.
The very best would have shorted at $100 and pressed aggressively at $50. That’s alpha.

PTON a great case study on shorting fallen angels. You could have shorted it for months between $100-120 and fought the noise daily and made 75-80pct or shorted at $50 on the blow up and made 50pct in 3 months. That’s why true shorting is what justifies fees.

Now the 2.5 vs. 12.5 may tell us a lot about where we are in the cycle and be an indicator in and of itself, but that's a different discussion than positioning.

@pmje73 Well in all fairness, for long only funds relative exposure is all that matters.  Absolute exposure is beyond irrelevant.

Don't think it is well understood that a long only PM can be up 100% and make zero bonus if their index is up 100.1%.

tweets.text: @pmje73 What worked ok for original strain may not be enough for omicron. But @zeynep has been on this for a long time, we should’ve upgraded all our masks as soon as shortage was over. They’re cheap.

@pmje73 It is what I struggle with most: A business you know with >80% certainty to be worthless, hitting ATHs, the urge to short 1-200bps e.g.

vs. the same co where the wheels have fallen off the story, it’s 40% off it’s highs, & worrying about scaling a short on something so oversold

@pmje73 Where do you usually find your best hidden math? Is it from imputing things like unit economics? I think that hidden math isn’t necessarily “hidden”, it’s just overlooked. Things like inventory days and days sales outstanding that many may think isnt a crucial detail, but it is.

@pmje73 Fighting the great narrative on the short side can be a long and arduous battle. Especially when the marginal buyer is 100% price insensitive (e.g. passive flows into some ESG theme). Generally had more success shorting after the narrative has started to crumble
@pmje73 Where do you think most mistakes lie? My guess would be it’s in the first construct.
@pmje73 Can you expand on what you mean by “hidden math”?
What’s your superpower?
@pmje73 @ChairliftCap Just curious, from your experience, would it apply to companies that are transforming or going through an inflection point?
@pmje73 One typically leads the other, just sometimes takes longer
@pmje73 Math without narrative sounds like a value trap?
@pmje73 @Post_Market I’m not convinced all sub 2bn funds want true alpha. It’s too hard. Agree about the rest.

@Post_Market How many single manager funds are even trying for true alpha? 

In theory you’re right, irl…
@pmje73 @Post_Market Agree. Was speaking more about those managing opm.
@pmje73 Few are truly like water.

@Post_Market Riding cycles is really really hard. Imo most should stick to a style and be honest about what they’re doing. 

Love the idea of someone always on top of the wave, but irl few can hold their breath long enough when they get rolled.
Would you rather underperform because you got the cycle wrong or because your style went out of favor? Same question about your managers as an LP.
Telco is pissing in cable’s broadband backyard while cable pisses in wireless’ smartphone backyard. Neither is good. But 10x 23 FCF on 2-3 names offsets a lot.

@ebitdaddy90 @pmje73 I need more info. But I don’t like to pay a lot for lsd ebit growth. Topline helps, if margin squeeze is transitory. But probably 10-12x ebit. But wd like to know about b/s and fcf conversion.

@pmje73 Absolutely when a fund needs the capital.

But some funds don't need the capital and the check-writers don't want to be left out when their allocator buddies are talking about the face-to-face with [big shot fund manager] they just had who told them [interesting mkt anecdote].

@pmje73 Nobody gets fired for going w the big guys. Also, hard to write 9 figure checks into small guys.

Long the alts $KKR

@pmje73 Hi Paul, just an observation, good shorting seems to rely on having good tactical trading/TA skills + timing. One also needs to think about covering after X profit or Y loss (to avoid blowups). 

Why is it anathema for PMs to try and apply the same skills on the long side?
@pmje73 Touché
@pmje73 Paul, love your contributions to this platform about stock selection and portfolio management, but what's with your obsession re: fees? Serious question.

PTON a great case study on shorting fallen angels. You could have shorted it for months between $100-120 and fought the noise daily and made 75-80pct or shorted at $50 on the blow up and made 50pct in 3 months. That’s why true shorting is what justifies fees.
@viggy_krishnan @pmje73 #3 is where being long term can help, but a lot of people will tell you it's a crutch for being wrong.
@pmje73 and the best ones https://t.co/0eemuAIdhW
@pmje73 @breadcrumbsre Here you go Sir https://t.co/VXwL8qoLDz
essentially, since mid-Nov 21 tech stocks with best FCF margins outperformed dramatically stocks with worst FCF margins
@IncognitusC @4drant @pmje73 The simple justification is that the very long term market returns have been circa 5-6% and so that’s an appropriate hurdle

@SahilBloom You don’t HAVE to LOSE money to make money. You have to RISK money to make money.

4 kinds of stocks I see rn.

data.text: @realdennishong @vardeinvest32 Just like market internals matter more for stock pickers than market performance, inflation inputs matter more than total headline inflation, and second derivative impacts on consumer spending and corporate margins matter most.

@realdennishong Said another way, consensus has priced in improving inflation pretty dramatically over the next few months and as a result pretty benign fed action.  Will consensus be right or wrong seems like an easier bet to analyze than what are the odds this is 1978 or 1999.

@bjvalueinvestor @realdennishong Not extly what I’m saying.  Rates can impact revenues and margins.  Rates do impact risk free rate and rates drive credit cycles which drive credit spreads which drive risk premiums.  All roads lead to rates. But in between rates and the market are those drivers of P and E.

@realdennishong Rates started msd and got to dd in 70s, P/E ratios went to low dd from mid teens. Today is 0 and 30+. GDP was 5 and inflation 6 for -1 stagflation. Today we are run rate 3 on gdp? And what is inflation? Not sure. Matters I think. Suspect 2022 will be a tale of 1h v 2h.

@realdennishong Stocks work when raising and economy still grows.  Stocks don’t work when stagflation 72/76/80 or popping a bubble like in 99. Rates v Spx is only a piece of the equation.  Not sure history is a guide. Need to assess why fed needs to raise and what that means.
